p: Currently, there is no vaccine against ZIKV in the market; however, some vaccines are under the developmental stage including a trial in animal model [ 55– 57]. As ZIKV is primarily transmitted through Aedes mosquitoes bite, mosquitoes control can be the prime strategies to control the ZIKV infection [ 58]. The standard Aedes mosquitoes’ control strategies have been mentioned by CDC and WHO [ 48]. The pregnant women have been suggested to avoid unnecessary travel to the areas of ongoing ZIKV transmission. The unprotected sexual contact with the person having the risk of ZIKV infection should be avoided.
